rounds.response:
The flop gave me an ace-high hand with a back-door nut-flush draw (need running hearts) and no straight or pair potential.  
Relative strength: good heads-up value—ace-high often wins unimproved—yet not so strong I want to build a huge pot.

Strategy:
- Small probing bet keeps the initiative, charges any worse ace, king-high, or gutter.
- Bet also fronts both turn and river, letting me manage pot size if the draw misses.

[Check] or [Call] would forfeit initiative and let villain control sizing if they take one.  
[Fold] is clearly wrong with ace-high.

Largest balanced bet here is about half-pot (around 20 chips). It keeps variance low vs a single opponent on a dry-ish board.

[Bet 20]

rounds.response:
I have Ace-high with a back-door nut-flush draw (two hearts in my hand and only one on the flop). The board is K♦ 4♣ 5♥ Q♠, so any Jack would give me the Broadway straight and any heart would give me the nut flush. I’m getting 3-to-1 pot odds on a call (120 : 40). Against a single opponent who has shown strength on both flop and turn, my Ace-high is probably behind right now, but I still have ~20 % equity with the overcard, gut-shot, and flush outs combined. At 990 chips I can afford the 40-chip call. I’ll take the card and re-evaluate the river.

[Call]
